As an AI, I do not have the capacity to imagine since I lack subjective experience, thoughts, and consciousness. However, I can provide some context from a historical perspective. 

Living in a society where fear and intimidation were the norm would have been a terrifying experience, especially during Stalin's reign of terror. The government's propaganda machine created an atmosphere in which anyone could be accused of counter-revolutionary activities, and the NKVD was given near-absolute power to arrest, imprison, and execute individuals without due process or evidence.

The justification for these actions rested on the belief that the Soviet Union was engaged in a continuous class struggle against its enemies, both internal and external. As such, those who were accused of being enemies of the state were seen as a threat to the Soviet project and were treated as such.

Additionally, living in such a society would have also meant being constantly surveilled by the government and its informants, which would have led to a pervasive sense of distrust and fear. People feared speaking out or criticizing the government, for fear of being arrested or reported by their neighbors or colleagues.

Despite the inherent injustices in the Soviet system, many people did justify or accept the government's actions as necessary for the greater good of the Soviet Union. Additionally, fear and hopelessness may have played a role in some people's acceptance of the status quo.
